awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Collaborative Research: An Experimental and Theoretical Study of the Microstructural and Electrochemical Stability of Solid Oxide Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Solid oxide cells are a rapidly developing technology for clean efficient conversion of fuels-to-electricity and electricity-to-fuels. While much of the development has been as solid oxide fuel cells for stationary power generation, important new applications have emerged that are critical for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, including electricity storage, conversion of renewable electricity to fuels, and fuel-flexible range extenders for electric vehicles. A key barrier to more widespread application of solid oxide cells is their limited operating lifetime - more research is needed to understand and ultimately mitigate degradation mechanisms that limit lifetime. This project provides a fundamental understanding of degradation processes that complements more practical studies, e.g., long-term fuel cell life tests, being carried out in industry. The project is achieving this understanding by developing and testing theoretical models based on measurements of device performance degradation and three-dimensional imaging of device damage. The project involves an industrial partner, Nissan, Inc., ensuring that cells are tested under application-relevant conditions. The results are relevant to many research communities, ranging from modelers who can utilize three-dimensional data and simulation methods, to industrial developers who can use the results to help improve their fuel cells. Graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students receive extensive training that will be valuable in their future careers - they find employment in energy-related industries, auto manufacturers, and many others. Student diversity is emphasized. Dissemination of the challenges and results with the public occur through two forums: Science Cafe in Evanston and the Ann Arbor Hands-On Museum, the latter attracts youngsters from surrounding communities that are disadvantaged (e.g., Ypsilanti) and/or rural (majority of communities in Washtenaw and its surrounding counties).

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project focuses on solid oxide cell performance and long-term stability; this is currently relevant because new applications involving cyclic operation introduce new degradation mechanisms. Three-dimensional imaging of fuel cell structure is carried out using focused ion beam - scanning electron microscopy, atom-probe tomography, and transmission X-ray microscopy, the latter done in a way that directly observes structural and chemical changes due to cell operation. These images are combined with three-dimensional simulations of electrode performance and structural evolution based on the phase field modeling, which will utilize high performance computing. This addresses a key challenge - to develop simulation models based on microstructural changes observed in short accelerated tests, and then apply them to accurately predict long-term (beyond 5 years) performance changes. This combination of 3D microstructures, validated simulation tools, and computationally intensive data analysis provides a framework that is broadly useful for design and discovery of electrode materials. Students receive training in state-of-the-art experimental and theoretical research methods, and directly interact with industrial and national laboratory researchers, the latter to utilize powerful three-dimensional imaging capabilities at Argonne and Brookhaven National Laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Solid oxide cells (SOCs) are key technologies in the future energy landscape due to their high power density and high efficiency. The solid oxide electrolysis cell (SOEC) in particular can yield high efficiency compared with alkaline and proton exchange membrane electrolyzers.  By operating at or near the thermoneutral voltage (, >90% electrical efficiency can be achieved when generating H2.  The high efficiency is largely due to the high operating SOEC temperature; however, the high temperature can lead to various degradation phenomena.  One type of microstructural evolution that appears to be exacerbated specifically by SOEC operating conditions is Ni migration in the Ni-YSZ fuel electrode, a net movement of Ni near the electrolyte often. Most reports of Ni migration, for SOECs typically operated at temperatures 700 - 800 C, have shown Ni migration away from the electrolyte.  The migration is often observed together with Ni forming isolated particles, but in other cases migration has been observed with evidence of isolated Ni particle formation.  

This project is a study of the microstructural and chemical evolution of solid oxide cells operated in electrolysis mode and fuel cell modes.  Such evolution typically gives rise to degradation of electrochemical performance.  The main aim of the research is to understand and ultimately mitigate degradation, as needed for more widespread application of these important energy conversion and storage devices.  The approach is a combination of electrochemical life testing, quantitative observation of microstructural evolution using three-dimensional (3D) tomography along with other techniques, and modeling to elucidate and predict how cell microstructure evolves and impacts electrochemical characteristics.  

The central aim of the project is to develop a fundamental understanding of the degradation processes that arise in operation of solid oxide cells in different operating modes. Electrolysis and reversible operation modes are particularly interesting because they have been shown to cause degradation mechanisms not seen in normal fuel cell operation, apparently resulting from extreme conditions in the electrodes and electrolyte.  Cyclic fuel cell operation, such as redox cycling and thermal cycling, is also known to cause degradation.  The project’s approach combines experimental observation – in which changes in microstructure and local chemistry during cell operation in various modes are studied using 3D tomographic methods – and theory – in which multiphysics phase-field models are used to fit and explain experimental data and ultimately predict microstructural/chemical evolution.  This allows identification of the underlying mechanisms by which applied current and overpotentials cause degradation. Furthermore, it is a key step in the development of mechanistic models with the potential to predict long-term solid oxide cell stability based on short-term accelerated test data.  Ultimately, this approach can lead to methods for reducing or eliminating degradation.  The present work considers both both thermal and current/potential degradation effects, whereas the focus in prior work was on only thermally induced changes.  

The project also has important educational, diversity, and outreach impacts.  Graduate and undergraduate students receive unique training including ceramic processing, electrochemical testing/analysis, characterization including 3D tomography, and modeling.   Educational impacts include augmentation of related classes, increasing the number of K-12 girls who pursue science by involving them in a paid summer research program, and involving high school teachers in research.

 


Last Modified: 08/09/2024
Modified by: Scott A Barnett
